definition: A share in the ownership of a company.
A tool or formula used to analyze stock price patterns and help make trading decisions.
Testing a trading strategy using historical price data to see how it would have performed.
Simulated trading with no real money at risk. It helps you practice without losing money.
A graph that shows how the value of your portfolio or strategy changes over time.
An indicator that shows the average price of a stock over a specific number of days. It smooths out price data to help identify trends.
Like the SMA, but gives more importance to recent prices. It reacts faster to price changes.
An indicator that measures how overbought or oversold a stock is. A value above 70 may mean 'overbought'; below 30 may mean 'oversold.'
A trend-following momentum indicator that shows the relationship between two EMAs. Often used to spot changes in trend direction.
The number of shares traded during a specific time period. High volume usually means strong interest in a stock.
An indication (from an indicator or rule) that it might be a good time to buy a stock.
An indication that it might be a good time to sell a stock.
A price level where a stock tends to stop falling and may bounce back up.
A price level where a stock tends to stop rising and may reverse downward.
The general direction of a stock's priceâ€”upward (bullish), downward (bearish), or sideways.
A type of price chart that shows the open, high, low, and close for each time period. Each 'candle' shows if the price went up (green) or down (red).
A condition that decides when to buy a stock in your strategy.
A condition that decides when to sell a stock in your strategy.
A short code used to identify a stock, such as AAPL for Apple Inc.
The amount of money you start with in your trading account.
